name: Tucker's Reagent
typical_results: For revealing grain structure in aluminum alloys, especially heat-treated materials. Good for showing precipitates.
preparation_notes: CAUTION: HF is extremely hazardous. Mix 45ml HCl, 15ml HNO₃, 15ml HF, and 25ml water in plastic container. Use fume hood and proper PPE.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 15-45 seconds. Swab if needed. Rinse immediately with copious water.
troubleshooting_notes: HF causes severe burns. Use in fume hood with proper PPE. Have calcium gluconate gel available. Good for heat-treated aluminum alloys.
storage_notes: Store in plastic container. Label clearly. Extremely hazardous - follow safety protocols.

name: Carpenters
typical_results: For chromium steels and stainless steels.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 5g CuCl₂ in 100ml HCl, then add 100ml ethanol.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Rinse with water and ethanol.
troubleshooting_notes: Similar formulation to other copper chloride etchants.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: Ti-AP-16
typical_results: Alternative etchant for titanium alloys. Reveals alpha and beta phases.
color_effects: Alpha phase light, beta phase dark
preparation_notes: CAUTION: HF is extremely hazardous. Mix 2ml HF, 5ml HNO₃, and 100ml water in plastic container. Use fume hood and proper PPE.
application_notes: Swab sample for 5-15 seconds. Do not immerse. Rinse immediately with copious water.
troubleshooting_notes: HF causes severe burns. Always use in fume hood with proper PPE. Have calcium gluconate gel available.
storage_notes: Store in plastic container. Label clearly. Extremely hazardous - follow safety protocols.

name: 10% Nital
typical_results: Most aggressive Nital concentration. For extremely hard materials that don't respond to lower concentrations.
preparation_notes: Mix 10 ml concentrated nitric acid with 90 ml ethanol. Add acid slowly to ethanol.
application_notes: Immerse for 25-50 seconds. Most aggressive - use very short times initially and monitor closely. Rinse thoroughly.
troubleshooting_notes: Use only for extremely hard steels that don't respond to 8% Nital. Very aggressive - monitor etching time very carefully to avoid over-etching.
storage_notes: Store in dark glass bottle. Shelf life: 3-6 months.

name: Glyceregia
typical_results: Excellent for austenitic stainless steels and nickel alloys. Reveals grain structure clearly.
preparation_notes: Mix 15ml HCl, 10ml HNO₃, and 10ml glycerol. Add acids to glycerol slowly. CAUTION: Exothermic reaction.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 20-40 seconds. Swab gently. Rinse immediately with water and ethanol.
troubleshooting_notes: Prepare fresh for best results. Glycerol slows reaction rate. Use fume hood.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Prepare fresh when needed. Shelf life: 1-2 weeks.

name: Sodium Metabisulfite (10%)
typical_results: For revealing prior austenite grain boundaries in quenched and tempered steels. Important for heat treatment analysis.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 10g sodium metabisulfite (Na₂S₂O₅) in 100ml distilled water. Prepare fresh solution.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Swab gently if needed. Rinse with water.
troubleshooting_notes: Prepare fresh for best results. Solution decomposes over time. Important for heat treatment analysis.
storage_notes: Store in dark bottle. Prepare fresh when needed. Shelf life: 1-2 days.

name: Weck's Etch
typical_results: Color etchant for stainless steels. Produces colored phases.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 4g KMnO₄ and 4g NaOH in 100ml water. Heat to 60°C.
application_notes: Immerse sample at 60°C for 60-120 seconds. Rinse with water.
troubleshooting_notes: Use hot for best results. Produces color contrast.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Prepare fresh when needed.

name: ASTM No. 30
typical_results: ASTM standard etchant for stainless steels and nickel alloys.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 5g CuCl₂ in 100ml HCl, then add 100ml ethanol.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Rinse with water and ethanol.
troubleshooting_notes: Standard ASTM etchant formulation.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: Keller's Reagent
typical_results: Standard etchant for aluminum alloys. Reveals grain structure and second phases.
preparation_notes: CAUTION: HF is extremely hazardous. Mix 2ml HF, 3ml HCl, 5ml HNO₃, and 190ml water in plastic container.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 10-20 seconds. Swab if needed. Rinse immediately with copious water.
troubleshooting_notes: HF causes severe burns. Use in fume hood with proper PPE. Have calcium gluconate gel available.
storage_notes: Store in plastic container. Label clearly. Extremely hazardous.

name: Barker's Reagent (Electrolytic)
typical_results: Electrolytic etchant for aluminum. Produces excellent grain boundary contrast and interference colors. Very effective for aluminum microstructures.
color_effects: Grain boundaries dark, interference colors visible
preparation_notes: CAUTION: Fluoboric acid is corrosive. Use concentrated fluoboric acid (HBF₄) as electrolyte. Use in fume hood with proper PPE.
application_notes: Use as electrolyte with aluminum or stainless steel cathode. Apply 15-30V DC, 0.1 A/cm² current density for 30-90 seconds. Sample is anode. Rinse thoroughly with water after etching.
troubleshooting_notes: Produces excellent interference colors for phase identification. Ensure good electrical contact. If no etching, check connections and increase voltage slightly.
storage_notes: Store in plastic container. Label clearly as corrosive. Shelf life: several months.

name: Beraha's Reagent
typical_results: Color etchant for stainless steels. Produces colored phases.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 20g Na₂S₂O₅ and 1g K₂S₂O₅ in 100ml water.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 60-120 seconds. Rinse with water.
troubleshooting_notes: Produces color contrast between phases.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several weeks.

name: Aqua Regia
typical_results: Very aggressive etchant for noble metals and some stainless steels. Excellent for revealing grain structure in difficult-to-etch materials.
preparation_notes: CAUTION: Extremely corrosive and produces toxic fumes. Mix 75ml concentrated HCl with 25ml concentrated HNO₃. Always add nitric acid to hydrochloric acid slowly. Prepare fresh - decomposes rapidly. Use in fume hood.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Swab gently if needed. Rinse immediately with copious water, then ethanol. Very aggressive - monitor closely.
troubleshooting_notes: Produces toxic chlorine and nitrosyl chloride fumes. Use only in fume hood with proper PPE. Prepare fresh for each use as it decomposes quickly. Very aggressive - may over-etch if left too long.
storage_notes: Cannot be stored - prepare fresh for each use. Decomposes within hours. Store component acids separately.

name: 8% Nital
typical_results: Very aggressive etchant for very hard steels. Use with caution.
preparation_notes: Mix 8 ml concentrated nitric acid with 92 ml ethanol. Add acid slowly to ethanol.
application_notes: Immerse for 20-40 seconds. Very aggressive - use shorter times initially. Rinse thoroughly.
troubleshooting_notes: Use for extremely hard steels. Monitor etching time very carefully.
storage_notes: Store in dark glass bottle. Shelf life: 3-6 months.

name: ASTM No. 97
typical_results: Electrolytic etchant for Fe-Cr-Ni alloys. Provides controlled etching for nickel alloys and stainless steels.
preparation_notes: CAUTION: KOH is caustic. Dissolve 187.5g potassium hydroxide (KOH) in 245ml distilled water. Use in fume hood with proper PPE.
application_notes: Use as electrolyte with stainless steel cathode. Apply 2.5V DC, 0.1 A/cm² current density for 5-15 seconds. Sample is anode. Rinse thoroughly with water after etching.
troubleshooting_notes: CAUTION: Caustic - use proper PPE. Provides controlled etching. Ensure good electrical contact. If no etching, check connections.
storage_notes: Store in plastic container. Label clearly as caustic. Shelf life: several months.

name: Nickel Etchant
typical_results: For nickel and nickel alloys. Reveals grain structure.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 5g CuCl₂ in 100ml HCl, then add 100ml ethanol.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. May require swabbing. Rinse with water and ethanol.
troubleshooting_notes: Works well on nickel and nickel-based alloys.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: 4% Picral
typical_results: Excellent for revealing pearlite structure. Does not attack ferrite grain boundaries as strongly as Nital.
preparation_notes: Mix 4 g picric acid with 100 ml ethanol. Warm slightly to dissolve. CAUTION: Picric acid is explosive when dry.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 10-20 seconds. Swab if needed. Rinse with ethanol then water.
troubleshooting_notes: Keep picric acid wet at all times. Never allow to dry. Store in water-wet condition.
storage_notes: Store in dark bottle, keep wet. Add water if solution dries. Extremely hazardous when dry.

name: Oberhoffer's Reagent
typical_results: Color etchant for revealing phosphorus segregation in steels and cast irons.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 50g CuCl₂ in 150ml HCl, then add 150ml ethanol and 50ml water.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Rinse with water and ethanol.
troubleshooting_notes: Produces color contrast showing phosphorus segregation.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: Waterless Kallings
typical_results: Waterless version of Kalling's reagent. Similar results to Kalling's No. 2.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 5g CuCl₂ in 100ml HCl, then add 100ml ethanol. No water added.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Rinse with water and ethanol.
troubleshooting_notes: Waterless formulation of Kalling's reagent.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: 0.5% HF
typical_results: Light etchant for aluminum alloys. Less aggressive than Keller's reagent. Good for sensitive microstructures.
preparation_notes: CAUTION: HF is extremely hazardous. Mix 0.5ml HF with 99.5ml water in plastic container. Use fume hood and proper PPE.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 10-20 seconds. Swab if needed. Rinse immediately with copious water.
troubleshooting_notes: HF causes severe burns. Use in fume hood with proper PPE. Have calcium gluconate gel available. Less aggressive than Keller's reagent.
storage_notes: Store in plastic container. Label clearly. Extremely hazardous.

name: 4% Nital
typical_results: Intermediate concentration between 3% and 5% Nital. Good balance for medium-hardness steels.
preparation_notes: Mix 4 ml concentrated nitric acid (HNO₃) with 96 ml ethanol. Add acid to ethanol slowly with stirring.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 12-25 seconds. Intermediate aggressiveness between 3% and 5% Nital. Rinse with ethanol then water.
troubleshooting_notes: Good intermediate option when 3% is too light and 5% is too aggressive. Adjust time based on material response.
storage_notes: Store in dark glass bottle. Shelf life: 3-6 months.

name: 10% Phosphoric Acid (Electrolytic)
typical_results: Electrolytic etchant for stainless steels. Good for revealing grain structure without over-etching.
preparation_notes: Mix 10ml concentrated phosphoric acid (H₃PO₄) with 100ml distilled water. Use as electrolyte in electrolytic etching setup.
application_notes: Use as electrolyte with stainless steel cathode. Apply 6V DC, 0.1 A/cm² current density for 30-60 seconds. Sample is anode. Rinse with water after etching.
troubleshooting_notes: Ensure good electrical contact. If no etching occurs, check connections and increase voltage slightly. If over-etching, reduce time or current density.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months. Solution is stable.

name: Kalling's No. 2
reveals: Austenite grain boundaries, sigma phase, carbides
typical_results: Excellent for austenitic stainless steels. Reveals grain boundaries and secondary phases.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 5g CuCl₂ in 100ml HCl, then add 100ml ethanol. Mix thoroughly.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. May require swabbing. Rinse with water and ethanol.
troubleshooting_notes: Works best on austenitic stainless steels. May over-etch if left too long.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: Kroll's Reagent
typical_results: Standard etchant for titanium alloys. Reveals alpha and beta phases with good contrast.
color_effects: Alpha phase light, beta phase dark
preparation_notes: CAUTION: HF is extremely hazardous. Mix 2-3ml HF, 5ml HNO₃, and 100ml water in plastic container. Use fume hood and proper PPE.
application_notes: Swab sample for 5-15 seconds. Do not immerse. Rinse immediately with copious water.
troubleshooting_notes: HF causes severe burns. Always use in fume hood with proper PPE. Have calcium gluconate gel available.
storage_notes: Store in plastic container. Label clearly. Extremely hazardous - follow safety protocols.

name: Fry's Reagent
typical_results: For chromium steels and stainless steels.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 5g CuCl₂ in 100ml HCl, then add 100ml ethanol.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Rinse with water and ethanol.
troubleshooting_notes: Similar formulation to other copper chloride etchants.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: Copper No. 2
typical_results: For copper alloys and bronzes. Reveals grain structure.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 5-10g FeCl₃ in 25ml HCl, then add 100ml water.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 20-40 seconds. Rinse with water.
troubleshooting_notes: May stain sample if over-etched. Reduce time if needed.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: 5% Nital
typical_results: More aggressive etchant for hard steels. Reveals martensite and bainite structures clearly.
preparation_notes: Mix 5 ml concentrated nitric acid with 95 ml ethanol. Add acid slowly to ethanol.
application_notes: Immerse for 15-30 seconds. More aggressive - use shorter times initially. Rinse thoroughly.
troubleshooting_notes: Use for very hard steels. Monitor etching time carefully to avoid over-etching.
storage_notes: Store in dark glass bottle. Shelf life: 3-6 months.

name: CU-PASS-SOL
typical_results: For copper and copper alloys. Reveals grain structure.
preparation_notes: Mix copper sulfate solution with ammonium hydroxide and water.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Rinse with water.
troubleshooting_notes: Good alternative to ammonium persulfate for copper.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several weeks.

name: Dichromate Etchant
typical_results: For copper and copper alloys. Reveals grain structure.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 10g K₂Cr₂O₇ in 100ml water, then add 5ml H₂SO₄ slowly.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Rinse with water.
troubleshooting_notes: CAUTION: Contains dichromate and sulfuric acid. Use with proper PPE.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: ASTM No. 3
typical_results: ASTM standard etchant. Similar to 5% Nital. Good for carbon and low-alloy steels.
preparation_notes: Mix 5ml concentrated nitric acid (HNO₃) with 100ml ethanol. Add acid to ethanol slowly with stirring.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 15-30 seconds. Rinse with ethanol then water. Dry with compressed air.
troubleshooting_notes: Similar to 5% Nital. If over-etched, reduce time. If under-etched, increase time slightly.
storage_notes: Store in dark glass bottle with tight cap. Keep away from light. Shelf life: 3-6 months if properly stored.

name: Klemm's Reagent
typical_results: Color etchant for stainless steels. Produces colored phases.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 50g Na₂S₂O₅ in 100ml water.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 60-120 seconds. Rinse with water.
troubleshooting_notes: Produces color contrast between phases.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several weeks.

name: Adler's Etchant
typical_results: Good for chromium steels and some stainless steels.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 5g CuCl₂ in 100ml HCl, then add 100ml ethanol.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Rinse with water and ethanol.
troubleshooting_notes: Similar to Kalling's but with different proportions.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: Ammonium Hydroxide + H₂O₂
typical_results: Standard etchant for copper and brass. Reveals grain boundaries and annealing twins. Fresh solution required for best results.
preparation_notes: Mix 50ml ammonium hydroxide (NH₄OH) with 50ml hydrogen peroxide (3% H₂O₂). Prepare fresh solution - decomposes quickly.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 10-30 seconds. Swab gently if needed. Rinse with water. Fresh solution works best.
troubleshooting_notes: Solution decomposes quickly - prepare fresh for each use. If no etching occurs, prepare new solution. Very common and effective for copper.
storage_notes: Cannot be stored - prepare fresh for each use. Decomposes within hours.

name: 3% Nital
typical_results: Similar to 2% Nital but more aggressive. Better for harder steels and bainitic structures.
color_effects: Pearlite darkens more, ferrite remains light
preparation_notes: Mix 3 ml concentrated nitric acid (HNO₃) with 97 ml ethanol. Add acid to ethanol slowly with stirring.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 10-20 seconds. More aggressive than 2% Nital. Rinse with ethanol then water.
troubleshooting_notes: Use for harder steels that don't respond well to 2% Nital. Reduce time if over-etching occurs.
storage_notes: Store in dark glass bottle. Shelf life: 3-6 months.

name: Vilella's Reagent
typical_results: Excellent for tool steels and high-speed steels. Reveals carbides clearly.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 1g picric acid in 5ml HCl, then add 100ml ethanol. CAUTION: Picric acid is explosive when dry.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 10-20 seconds. Rinse with ethanol then water.
troubleshooting_notes: Keep picric acid wet. Never allow to dry. Use fresh solution.
storage_notes: Store in dark bottle, keep wet. Extremely hazardous when dry.

name: Copper No. 1
typical_results: For copper and copper alloys. Reveals grain boundaries and annealing twins.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 10g (NH₄)₂S₂O₈ in 100ml distilled water. Prepare fresh solution.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Swab gently. Rinse with water.
troubleshooting_notes: Prepare fresh for best results. Solution decomposes over time.
storage_notes: Store in dark bottle. Prepare fresh when needed. Shelf life: 1-2 days.

name: ASTM No. 2
typical_results: ASTM standard etchant for revealing pearlite structure. Does not attack ferrite grain boundaries as strongly as Nital.
preparation_notes: Mix 4g picric acid with 100ml ethanol. Warm slightly to dissolve. CAUTION: Picric acid is explosive when dry. Keep wet at all times.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 10-20 seconds. Swab if needed. Rinse with ethanol then water.
troubleshooting_notes: Keep picric acid wet at all times. Never allow to dry. Store in water-wet condition. If over-etched, reduce time.
storage_notes: Store in dark bottle, keep wet. Add water if solution dries. Extremely hazardous when dry. Never allow to dry completely.

name: Ferric Chloride
typical_results: Good for copper alloys and bronzes. Reveals grain structure.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 5-10g FeCl₃ in 25ml HCl, then add 100ml water.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 20-40 seconds. Rinse with water.
troubleshooting_notes: May stain sample if over-etched. Reduce time if needed.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: 10% Oxalic Acid (Electrolytic)
typical_results: Electrolytic etchant for stainless steels. Reveals grain boundaries and secondary phases. Less aggressive than chemical etchants.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 10g oxalic acid dihydrate in 100ml distilled water. Use as electrolyte in electrolytic etching setup.
application_notes: Use as electrolyte with stainless steel cathode. Apply 6V DC, 0.1 A/cm² current density for 30-60 seconds. Sample is anode. Rinse with water after etching.
troubleshooting_notes: Ensure good electrical contact. If no etching occurs, check connections and increase voltage slightly. If over-etching, reduce time or current density.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months. Solution is stable.

name: ASTM No. 157
typical_results: ASTM standard etchant for stainless steels and nickel alloys.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 5g CuCl₂ in 100ml HCl, then add 100ml ethanol.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Rinse with water and ethanol.
troubleshooting_notes: Standard ASTM etchant formulation.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: 10% Perchloric Acid (Electrolytic)
typical_results: Electrolytic etchant for stainless steels and nickel alloys. Very effective for revealing grain structure.
preparation_notes: CAUTION: Perchloric acid is extremely dangerous and can explode. Mix 10ml perchloric acid (70%) with 90ml glacial acetic acid. Use only in specialized fume hood designed for perchloric acid. Never use with organic materials.
application_notes: Use as electrolyte with stainless steel cathode. Apply 20V DC, 0.5 A/cm² current density for 20-40 seconds at room temperature. Sample is anode. Rinse thoroughly with water after etching.
troubleshooting_notes: CAUTION: Perchloric acid is extremely hazardous and can form explosive perchlorate salts. Use only in specialized perchloric acid fume hood. Never allow to dry. Clean all surfaces thoroughly after use. Very effective but requires extreme caution.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle in specialized perchloric acid storage area. Label clearly as extremely hazardous. Shelf life: prepare fresh when needed.

name: Marble's Reagent
typical_results: For copper and brass. Reveals grain boundaries and twins.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 10g CuSO₄ in 50ml water, then add 50ml NH₄OH.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Rinse with water.
troubleshooting_notes: Good for revealing annealing twins in copper.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several weeks.

name: Inconel Etchant
typical_results: Specifically for Inconel and nickel-based superalloys.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 5g CuCl₂ in 100ml HCl, then add 100ml ethanol.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. May require swabbing. Rinse with water and ethanol.
troubleshooting_notes: Works well on Inconel series alloys.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: Ammonium Persulfate
typical_results: Excellent for copper and brass. Reveals grain boundaries and annealing twins clearly.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 10g (NH₄)₂S₂O₈ in 100ml distilled water. Prepare fresh solution.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Swab gently. Rinse with water.
troubleshooting_notes: Prepare fresh for best results. Solution decomposes over time.
storage_notes: Store in dark bottle. Prepare fresh when needed. Shelf life: 1-2 days.

name: Murakami's Reagent
typical_results: Excellent for tungsten carbides and hard metals. Reveals carbide distribution.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 10g K₃Fe(CN)₆ and 10g KOH in 100ml water. Prepare fresh.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. May require heating to 50-60°C for some materials.
troubleshooting_notes: Can be used hot for better results on hard materials.
storage_notes: Store in dark bottle. Prepare fresh when needed.

name: 2% Nital
typical_results: Reveals ferrite grain boundaries and pearlite colonies. Darkens pearlite, leaves ferrite light.
preparation_notes: Mix 2 ml concentrated nitric acid (HNO₃) with 98 ml ethanol (95% or absolute). Add acid to ethanol slowly with stirring. Store in glass bottle.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 5-15 seconds. Swab gently if needed. Rinse immediately with ethanol, then water. Dry with compressed air.
troubleshooting_notes: If over-etched (too dark), reduce time or concentration. If under-etched, increase time slightly. Ensure fresh etchant for best results.
storage_notes: Store in dark glass bottle with tight cap. Keep away from light. Shelf life: 3-6 months if properly stored.

name: ASTM No. 1
typical_results: ASTM standard general-purpose etchant. Similar to Nital but with variable concentration. Good for carbon and low-alloy steels.
preparation_notes: Mix 1-5ml concentrated nitric acid (HNO₃) with 100ml ethanol. Adjust concentration based on material hardness. Add acid to ethanol slowly with stirring.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 10-30 seconds. Adjust time based on concentration used. Rinse with ethanol then water. Dry with compressed air.
troubleshooting_notes: Start with lower concentration (1-2%) for softer steels. Increase concentration for harder materials. If over-etched, reduce concentration or time.
storage_notes: Store in dark glass bottle with tight cap. Keep away from light. Shelf life: 3-6 months if properly stored.

name: Chromic Acid (Electrolytic)
typical_results: Electrolytic etchant for stainless steels and nickel alloys. Good for revealing grain structure without over-etching.
preparation_notes: CAUTION: Chromic acid is highly toxic and carcinogenic. Dissolve 10g CrO₃ in 100ml distilled water. Use in fume hood with proper PPE.
application_notes: Use as electrolyte with stainless steel cathode. Apply 6V DC, 0.1 A/cm² current density for 60-120 seconds. Sample is anode. Rinse thoroughly with water after etching.
troubleshooting_notes: CAUTION: Chromic acid is a known carcinogen. Use only in fume hood with full PPE. Ensure good electrical contact. If no etching, check connections.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle with tight cap. Label clearly as toxic and carcinogenic. Shelf life: several months.

name: Stead's Reagent
ingredients: [{"name": "Copper Chloride", "role": "etching agent", "amount": "10g"}, {"name": "Magnesium Chloride", "role": "etching agent", "amount": "40g"}, {"name": "Hydrochloric Acid", "role": "etching agent", "amount": "20ml"}, {"name": "Water", "role": "solvent", "amount": "1000ml"}]
typical_results: Specifically for revealing graphite in cast iron. Colors graphite and reveals matrix structure.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 10g CuCl₂ and 40g MgCl₂ in 1000ml water, then add 20ml HCl. Mix thoroughly.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 60-120 seconds. Swab gently if needed. Rinse with water.
troubleshooting_notes: Excellent for revealing graphite distribution in cast irons. May require longer times for some materials.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: Winsteard's Reagent
typical_results: For chromium steels and stainless steels.
preparation_notes: Dissolve 5g CuCl₂ in 100ml HCl, then add 100ml ethanol.
application_notes: Immerse sample for 30-60 seconds. Rinse with water and ethanol.
troubleshooting_notes: Similar to other copper chloride based etchants.
storage_notes: Store in glass bottle. Shelf life: several months.

name: Modified Kroll's Reagent
typical_results: Less aggressive version of Kroll's reagent. Good for sensitive titanium microstructures.
color_effects: Alpha phase light, beta phase dark
preparation_notes: CAUTION: HF is extremely hazardous. Mix 1ml HF, 3ml HNO₃, and 100ml water in plastic container. Use fume hood and proper PPE.
application_notes: Swab sample for 5-15 seconds. Do not immerse. Rinse immediately with copious water.
troubleshooting_notes: HF causes severe burns. Always use in fume hood with proper PPE. Have calcium gluconate gel available. Less aggressive than standard Kroll's.
storage_notes: Store in plastic container. Label clearly. Extremely hazardous - follow safety protocols.

name: Al-NaOH Etchant
typical_results: For aluminum alloys. Reveals grain structure.
preparation_notes: CAUTION: NaOH is caustic. Dissolve 10-20g NaOH in 100ml water. Use at 50°C.
application_notes: Immerse sample at 50°C for 30-60 seconds. Rinse immediately with water.
troubleshooting_notes: Use hot for better results. CAUTION: Caustic - use proper PPE.
storage_notes: Store in plastic container. Label clearly. Caustic hazard.
